newsitem.title: UK: AB Air aims for low-rate UK-Lisbon cargo.
newsitem.headline: AB Air aims for low-rate UK-Lisbon cargo.

text.p: AB Airlines, which plans to start a twice-daily London Gatwick-Lisbon scheduled passenger BAC 1-11 service from May 1, said it will be selling cargo space at the low rate end of the market.
But cargo manager Martin Hawkes said he hoped to keep yields up by attracting high-value shipments such as human remains and also perishables, along with general freight.
"Depending on passenger load, we will have 500 kg to 1.5 tonnes cargo capacity on each flight to sell," he told Reuters.
"Assuming we can negotiate reasonably priced handling costs at Lisbon, I hope to keep general rates down to about 0.50-0.60 stg per kg," he said.
AB Airlines is part of the AB Airlines Group, which also incorporates Air Bristol, Air Belfast and AB Shannon.
It has been operating three daily Shannon-Gatwick BAC 1-11 flights since December 1995, said Hawkes.
"These have connected with other carriers' London flights to and from the United States, eastern Europe and the Far East," he added.

"We have done particularly well carrying electronic goods manufactured in the mini-Silicon Valley area near Shannon, despite attracting strong competition from truckers and Ryanair, which trucks to and from Dublin," said Hawkes.
He said he soon hoped to appoint a cargo general sales agent for AB in Lisbon.
